title: Update regarding BankOne
story_body:
BankOne's Q2 operations have been impacted by the ongoing industry-wide shortage of high-performance, low-latency networking gear, specifically 100GbE switches and routers. This bottleneck has resulted in a 30% reduction in BANKO's data center capacity expansion plans, as the company struggles to procure sufficient quantities of the requisite hardware.

At the heart of the issue lies the scarcity of merchant silicon, specifically the Broadcom Trident 3 and Tomahawk 3 ASICs, which are crucial components in the manufacture of high-end networking equipment. The shortage has been exacerbated by the recent surge in demand for cloud and edge infrastructure, driving up lead times for these critical components to 20-24 weeks.

BANKO's data center architecture, built around a spine-leaf topology, relies heavily on these high-performance switches to maintain optimal east-west traffic flow and minimize latency. The company's internal benchmarks indicate that the substitute gear, sourced from secondary suppliers, falls short of the required specs, with packet loss rates exceeding 0.5% and average round-trip times (RTT) increasing by 10-15%.

Industry insiders point to the broader sector issue, citing the lack of diversity in the supply chain and the over-reliance on a limited number of merchant silicon vendors. "This is not just a BANKO problem," noted a senior network architect at a rival firm. "The entire industry is feeling the pinch, and it's going to take a concerted effort to resolve the shortage and get back to meeting the demands of our customers."

As the shortage persists, BANKO is exploring alternative solutions, including the adoption of software-defined networking (SDN) and network functions virtualization (NFV) to optimize resource utilization and mitigate the impact on its operations. However, these efforts are expected to take several quarters to come to fruition, leaving the company to navigate the challenging landscape in the near term.
